comment.author: 32573662@N00
comment._content: I'm no botanist, but based on the flowers we can probably call it Passiflora sp. at least. Most passion fruit vines that I've seen have lobed leaves, but P. alata has ovate single-lobed leaves and is native to the Amazon. Possibly also P. quadrangularis.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32573662@N00] This is a great reference, severinus. Thank you!  I'll forward this to my colleagues on the Field Notebook Project, and perhaps we can update these records. 

All best, 

Susannah
Smithsonian Institution Archives

comment.author: 68587888@N00
comment._content: Yes, Passiflora section Laurifoliae.  I will try to find the species.  Is there a collection number associated with this, or a date?

comment.author: 92033577@N00
comment._content: Wonderful the expertise that can be found on the web!--just by asking!

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content:
We couldn't agree more, mystuart!  Many thanks to severinus for sharing your expertise and to cpf1 for your input as a Smithsonian Research Associate.  We'll work with our team to get the caption updated.  Many thanks to you both!

All the best,
Carolyn Sheffield
Field Book Project

comment.author: 21356477@N04
comment._content: In the flesh so to speak: the photographer (Andre Cardoso) a professional botanist like cpf1 (comments above) works for the Museu Goeldi & has many more images in his stream: www.flickr.com/photos/maracuja_rama/galleries/72157625417...

comment.author: 30743267@N06
comment._content: Dear Passiflorae, thanks for your comment, but as a professional botanist, i´m justa a list of plants maker, that occasionally had discovered and described some new species. While (cpf1) Dr. Christian Feuillet is one of the experts in the neotropical Passiflora, of which I am a fan. He has described more than 40 new species of Passiflora

comment.author: 21356477@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/andre_cardoso] you are both my heroes: discovering and recording fascinating species for science & that the rest of us enjoy to learn about. Well, there is your challenge to catch up with Dr Feuillet: just 30+ species to go! And as you are early in your career there is no reason not to find them - the Amazon is huge! Thank you for sharing your discoveries on Flickr.

comment.author: 29050464@N06
comment._content: Added to commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Passiflora_acuminata --and thanks to all for the ID & interesting discussion.
